author: odyxes
content: Hello I have a somewhat question about the pseudo-randomness described in the spec, should I ask it here or is there a more suitable channel ?

author: odyxes
content:
In the specs we can see that the randao mix of an epoch is computed with the randao reveal of each received block. But I wonder, what if a validator sees a block which turns out to not belong to the canonical chain ? 
I donâ€™t see the part where the randao reveal is subtracted from the randao mix. I understand that being added with a xor we can remove it easily but I don't see in the specs where this process is explained...

author: ajsutton
content: You never need to remove blocks that aren't part of the chain - you always start from the state of the parent of the block you're importing.  So blocks that aren't part of that chain never have any effect on that state (they affect the state from their fork).

author: odyxes
content: I don't speak about removing blocks, I am wondering what is the right behaviour to have in order to compute the seed. And particularly, I am asking whether the randao mix of each epoch is computed with every block of this epoch or only the ones in the canonical chain (which is the chain given by the fork choice)

author: ajsutton
content: Same answer. ðŸ™‚ The randao mix is in the state. Stop thinking canonical or not and start thinking about forked chains updating a state that is specific to their fork.

author: odyxes
content:
Ok I see, thank you !
So just to be sure, each fork has its own randao mix ?
